{{Anime and manga}}
[[Manga]], or Japanese [[comics]], have appeared in translation in many different languages in different countries. France represents about 40% of the European manga market and in 2011 manga represented 40% of the comics being published in the country.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2004-02-04/manga-mania-in-france |title=Manga-mania in France |date=2004-02-04|accessdate= 2011-01-29|work=[[Anime News Network]]}}</ref> In 2007, 70% of the comics sold in Germany were manga. In the [[United States]], manga comprises a small (but growing) [[industry]], especially when compared to the inroads that [[anime|Japanese animation]] has made in the USA. One example of a manga publisher in the [[United States]], [[VIZ Media]], functions as the American affiliate of the Japanese publishers [[Shogakukan]] and [[Shueisha]]. The UK has fewer manga publishers than the U.S.{{Citation needed|date=January 2014}}
==Flipping== Since written Japanese fiction usually flows from right to left, manga artists draw and publish this way in Japan. When first translating various titles into Western languages, publishers reversed the artwork and layouts in a process known as "flipping", so that readers could follow the books from left-to-right. However, various creators (such as [[Akira Toriyama]]) did not approve of the modification of their work in this way, and requested that foreign versions retain the right-to-left format of the originals.{{Citation needed|date=January 2014}} Soon, due both to fan demand and to the requests of creators, more publishers began offering the option of right-to-left formatting, which has now become commonplace in North America. Left-to-right formatting has gone from the rule to the exception.
Translated manga often includes notes on details of [[Japanese culture]] that foreign audiences may not find familiar.
One company, [[TOKYOPOP]] (founded 1997), produces manga in the United States with the right-to-left format as a highly publicized point-of-difference.{{Citation needed|date=January 2014}}
==Asia==
===China===
The Chinese Ministry of Culture announced in 2015 that it has blacklisted 38 Japanese anime and manga titles from distribution in China, including popular series like [[Death Note]] and [[Attack on Titan]] online or in print, citing "scenes of violence, pornography, terrorism and crimes against public morality." <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2015-06-09/china-blacklists-attack-on-titan-death-note-36-more-anime-manga/.89055|date=2015-06-09|publisher=Anime News Network|title=China blacklists attack on titan death note 36 more anime manga}}</ref>
===Indonesia=== Manga in Indonesia is published by [[Elex Media Komputindo]], [[Acolyte inc.|Acolyte]], [[Level Comic]], [[M&C (publisher)|M&C]] and [[Gramedia]], and has greatly influenced Indonesia's original comic industry.
The wide distribution of [[scanlations]] actually contributes to the growth of publication of bootleg manga, which is printed in lower quality. One of the most notable publisher is Seventh Heaven which publishes bootleg version of [[One Piece]]. Many popular titles, such as [[Bleach (manga)|Bleach]], Loki, Magister Nagi, Rose Hip Zero, and [[Kingdom Hearts]], have been pirated, which draws controversy toward manga readers in Indonesia.
===Philippines=== Manga in the Philippines were imported from the USA and were sold only in specialty stores and in limited copies. The first manga in Filipino language is [[Doraemon]] which was published by J-Line Comics and was then followed by [[Case Closed (manga)|Case Closed]].
A few local publishing companies like [[VIVA-PSICOM Publishing]] feature manga created by local artists whose stories are usually based from popular written books from the writing site [[Wattpad]] and are read from left to right instead of the usual right-to-left format for Japanese manga. The very first commercial local manga is [[She Died]], an adaptation of the book written by Wattpad writer HaveYouSeenThisGirl. The art was done by Enjelicious.
In 2015, [[VIVA-PSICOM Publishing]] has announced that they will start publishing manga titles in the Filipino language with the line-up starting with [[Hiro Mashima]]'s [[Fairy Tail]] and [[Isayama Hajime]]'s [[Attack on Titan]].
In 2015, [[Boy's Love]] manga became popular through the introduction of BL manga by printing company BLACKink. Among the first BL titles to be printed were Poster Boy, Tagila, and Sprinters, all were written in [[Filipino language|Filipino]]. BL manga have become bestsellers in the top three bookstore companies in the Philippines since their introduction in 2015.
===Singapore=== The company [[Chuang Yi]] publishes manga in English and [[Chinese language|Chinese]] in [[Singapore]]; some of Chuang Yi's English-language titles are also imported into [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]] and the [[Philippines]] by [[Madman Entertainment]]. Singapore also has its own official Comics Society, led by manga artist [[Wee Tian Beng]], illustrator of the [[Dream Walker (comic)|Dream Walker]] series.
===Thailand=== In [[Thailand]], before 1992, almost all available manga were fast, unlicensed, poor quality bootlegs. However, due to copyright laws, this has changed and copyrights protect nearly all published manga. Thailand's prominent manga publishers include [[Nation Multimedia Group|Nation Edutainment]], Siam Inter Comics, Vibulkij, and [[Bongkoch Publishing|Bongkoch]].
Many parents in Thai society are not supportive of manga. In October 2005, there was a television programme broadcast about the dark side of manga with exaggerated details, resulted in many manga being banned. The programme received many complaints and issued an apology to the audience.
In 2015, [[Boy's Love]] manga have become popular in mainstream Thai consumers, leading to television series adapted from BL manga stories since 2016.
==Europe==
===France===
===="French exception"==== France has a particularly strong and diverse manga market. Many works published in France belong to genres not well represented outside Japan, such as too adult-oriented drama, or too experimental and ''avant-garde'' works. Early editors like [[Tonkam]] have published Hong-Kong authors ([[Andy Seto]], Yu & Lau) or Korean authors (Kim Jae-hwan, Soo & Il, Wan & Weol and [[Hyun Se Lee]]) in their ''manga'' collection during 1995/1996 which is quite uncommon. Also, some Japanese authors, such as [[Jiro Taniguchi]], are relatively unknown in other western countries but received much acclaim in France.
Since its introduction in the 1990s, ''manga'' publishing and ''anime'' broadcasting have become intertwined in France, where the most popular and exploited ''shōnen'', ''[[shōjo]]'' and ''[[seinen]]'' TV series were imported in their paper version. Therefore, Japanese books ("manga") were naturally and readily accepted by a large juvenile public who was already familiar with the series and received the ''manga'' as part of their own culture. A strong parallel backup was the emergence of Japanese video games, [[Nintendo]]/[[Sega]], which were mostly based on ''manga'' and ''anime'' series.
====Nippon Animation era (1978–1986)==== [[File:Grendizer.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Possibly the first ''anime'' introduced into France: ''[[UFO Robot Grendizer]]'' (1978), an introduction to ''manga'' culture. The opening theme, by [[Saban]], became an instant hit.]]
Producer [[Jean Chalopin]] contacted some Japanese studios, such as Toei<ref>[http://j.knoertzer.free.fr/chalopin.htm The Attic of ITAF] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819003804/http://j.knoertzer.free.fr/chalopin.htm |date=August 19, 2006 }}, Accessed 2009-03-10 {{fr icon}}</ref> (who did ''Grendizer''); and [[Tokyo Movie Shinsha]], [[Studio Pierrot]] and [[Studio Junio]] produced French-Japanese series. Even though made completely in Japan by character-designers such as [[Shingo Araki]], the first Chalopin production of this type, ''[[Ulysses 31]]'' took thematic inspiration from the Greek ''[[Odyssey]]'' and graphic influence from [[Stanley Kubrick]]'s ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]''. ''[[Ulysses 31]]'' went on sale in 1981, other shows produced by [[DiC Entertainment]] followed in 1982, ''[[Jayce and the Wheeled Warriors]]'', ''[[Mysterious Cities of Gold]]'', later ''[[M.A.S.K. (TV series)|M.A.S.K.]]'', etc. Such series were popular enough to allow the introduction of licensed products such as tee shirts, toys, stickers, mustard glass, mugs or ''[[keshi]]''. Also followed a wave of ''anime'' adaptations of European tales by Studio Pierrot and mostly by the [[Nippon Animation]] studio, ''e.g.'' [[Johanna Spyri]]'s ''[[Heidi, Girl of the Alps]]'' (1974), [[Waldemar Bonsels]]'s ''[[Maya the Honey Bee]]'' (1975), [[Hector Malot]]'s ''[[Nobody's Boy: Remi]]'' (1977), [[Cécile Aubry]]'s ''[[Belle and Sebastian (Japanese TV series)|Belle and Sebastian]]'' (1980), or [[Jules Verne]]'s ''[[Around the World with Willy Fog]]'' (1983), notable adaptation of American works were [[Mark Twain]]'s ''[[Tom Sawyer no Boken|Adventures of Tom Sawyer]]'' (1980) and [[Alexander Key]]'s ''[[Future Boy Conan]]''. Interesting cases are [[Alexandre Dumas, père]]'s ''[[The Three Musketeers]]'' adapted to ''[[Dogtanian and the Three Muskehounds]]'' (1981) and [[Sir Arthur Conan Doyle]]'s [[Sherlock Holmes]] become ''[[Sherlock Hound]]'' (1984), both turned human characters into [[Anthropomorphism|anthropomorph]] animals.
Such anthropomophism in tales comes from old and common storytelling traditions in both Japanese and French cultures, including the ''[[Chōjū giga]]'' ''[[emaki]]'' (the true origins of ''manga'') of [[Toba Sōjō]] (1053–1140), and the animal fables of [[Jean de La Fontaine]] (1621–1695). Changing humans to anthropomorphized dogs reflects a known form of [[Cynicism (contemporary)|Cynicism]]: etymologically speaking, the bite of the [[Cynicism (philosophy)|Cynic]] comes from the fact he is a dog (''cyno'' means "dog" in Greek). The adaptations of these popular tales made easier the acceptance and assimilation of semi-Japanese cultural products in countries such as France, Italy or Spain. The localization including credits removal by [[Saban]] or [[DiC]], was such that even today, twenty or thirty years later, most of French adults who have watched series like ''[[Calimero]]'' (1974) adapted from an Italian novel, ''[[Wanpaku Omukashi Kum Kum]]'' (1975), ''[[Barbapapa]]'' (1977) adapted from a French novel, or ''[[Monchichi]]'' (1980) as kids don't even know they were not local animation but "Japananimation" created in Japan.
====Toei era (1987–1996)==== [[File:Affiche Film France.png|right|thumb|150px|In 1991, ''[[Akira (1988 film)|Akira]]'', one of the first ''anime'' feature films released in France. "OST CD and manga now on sale".]]
In 1986 and 1987 three new private or privatized television channels appeared on French airwaves. An aggressive struggle for audience, especially on children television shows, started between the two public and the two private channels. After the private channels lost market share, they counter-attacked with a non-Japanese lineup, mostly American productions such as [[Hanna-Barbera]]. This ploy failed, and TF1 remained pre-eminent in children's TV shows with its Japanese licenses.
In 1991 French theaters showed an ''anime'' feature-film for the first time: [[Katsuhiro Otomo]]'s ''[[Akira (1988 film)|Akira]]'', a teen-rated, SF movie supported by manga publisher Glénat. TF1 Video edited the video ([[VHS]]) version for the French market, and ''Akira'' quickly became an ''anime'' reference. However, Japanese animation genre became massively exploited by TV shows from the late 1980s onwards, most notably the cult [[Dorothée|Club Dorothée]] show (mostly dedicated to [[Toei Company|Toei]] [[anime]] and [[tokusatsu]] series). In fact, the commercial relationship between the Japanese studio and the French show producers were so good, that the French presenter was even featured in a [[Metal Hero Series]] episode as guest star.
Just as in a Japanese ''manga'' series magazine, the Club Dorothée audience voted by phone or [[minitel]] to select and rank their favourite series. Top-ranked series continued the following week, others stopped. The most popular series were ''[[Dragon Ball (franchise)|Dragon Ball]]'' and later its sequel, ''[[Dragon Ball Z]]'', which became number one, and was nicknamed ''le chouchou'' ("the favorite") by the show presenter, Dorothée. As the series kept number one for several months, Dorothée invited [[Akira Toriyama]] ([[Toei Animation]]), creator of the series, on the TV show studio to introduce him to the French audience and award him a prize in the name of the TV show.
[[Saint Seiya]] was another ''anime'' series to achieve popularity in France. It showed more violence – directed towards an older audience – than the Nippon Animation studio ''shōnen''/''shōjo'' series of the 1970s and 1980s. Notable Toei and non-Toei ''anime'' series broadcast by that time on French TV included ''[[Captain Tsubasa]]'', ''[[Robotech]]'', ''[[High School! Kimengumi]]'' and ''[[Kinnikuman]]''. This cult TV show ran from 1987 to 1997.
====Generational conflict around manga (1990 to 1995)==== [[Glénat (publisher)|Glénat]] published the first manga issued in France, ''[[Akira (manga)|Akira]]'', in 1990 — supported by the respected newspaper ''[[Libération]]'' and by the national TV channel [[Antenne 2]]. Followers included ''[[Dragon Ball (franchise)|Dragon Ball]]'' (1993), ''[[Appleseed (manga)|Appleseed]]'' (1994), ''[[Ranma 1/2]]'' (1994) and five others. In the mid-1990s, ''manga'' magazines in B5 size like ''Kameha'' (Glénat) and ''Manga Player'' (MSE) were available.
At the same time a controversy arose among some parents. In particular, the conservative association ''[[:fr:Familles de France|Familles de France]]'' started a media polemic about the undesirable contents, such as violence, portrayed in the Club Dorothée, a kids' TV show. By this time, a generational conflict had arisen between the young fans of "Japanimation" (in use until ''anime'' became mainstream) and the older ''Japoniaiseries'' (a pejorative pun for ''Japonaiseries'', literally "Japanese stuff" and "''niaiseries''", "simpleton stuff"). [[Ségolène Royal]] even published a book, ''Le Ras le bol des bébés zappeurs'' in which manga are described as decadent dangerous and violent. She hasn't changed her position on that topic yet. The same adult content controversy was applied to ''[[hentai]]'' manga, including the notorious, "forbidden", ''[[Shin Angel]]'' by [[U-Jin]], published by pioneers such as [[Samourai Editions]] or [[Katsumi Editions]] and later to magazines. The first ''hentai'' series magazine, "Yoko", featured softcore series like Yuuki's ''[[Tropical Eyes]]''. It was first issued in late 1995. The same year, the noir and ultra-violent series, ''[[Gunnm]]'' (aka ''Battle Angel Alita''), was serialized in a slim, monthly edition. Around the same period a hardcore version of Yoko magazine ''Okaz'' was issued.
====Anime clearance and manga emergence (1996 to 1998)==== In 1996 the production group of Club Dorothée, broadcast on private channel [[TF1]], set up a cable/satellite channel dedicated to ''manga'' and ''anime''. The new channel changed its name to [[Mangas (TV network)|''Mangas'']] in 1998: the concepts of ''anime'' and ''manga'' have become intertwined in France, and ''manga'' actually became the mainstream generic term to designate the two media. The channel broadcasts former discontinued series from the Club Dorothée both to nostalgic adults and to new and younger generations.
====Cultural integration and revival (1999 to 2013)==== In late 1999 respected newspapers such as ''[[Le Monde]]'' gave critical acclaim to [[Hiroyuki Okiura]]'s ''[[Jin-Roh]]'', and in 2000, [[Hayao Miyazaki]]'s ''[[Princess Mononoke]]'' became a commercial success.
In 2004, [[Mamoru Oshii]]'s ''[[Innocence: Ghost in the Shell 2]]'' became the first animation finalist in the prestigious [[Cannes Film Festival|International Film Festival of Cannes]], which demonstrates a radical perspective change and a social acceptance of Japanese ''anime''/''manga''. Since 2005, contemporary Japanese series such as ''[[Naruto]]'', ''[[Initial D]]'', ''[[Great Teacher Onizuka]]'', ''[[Blue Gender]]'' or ''[[Gunslinger Girl]]'' appeared on new, analog/digital terrestrial (public) and on satellite/broadband (private) channels. As the highly aggressive competition who raged once between, the sole two or three available channels no more exists in the new, vast, and segmented French TV offer, the ''anime'' is doing a revival in France. In 2011, 40% of the comics published in France were manga.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.otakia.com/39475/actualites/bilan-des-manga-en-2011-naruto-encore-numero-1/ |title=Bilan des manga en 2011 : Naruto encore numéro 1 |author=Jérôme Cognet |date=2012-02-06|accessdate= 2012-02-07|work=Otakia|language=French}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.otakia.com/39462/actualites/bilan-de-la-bande-dessinee-en-2011-un-secteur-stable/|title=Bilan de la bande-dessinée en 2011 : un secteur stable|author=Jérôme Cognet |date=2012-01-30|accessdate= 2012-02-07|work=Otakia|language=French}}</ref> In 2013, there were 41 publishers of manga in France and, together with other Asian comics, manga represented around 40% of new comics releases in the country,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/booknews/comics/article/61030-strong-french-manga-market-begins-to-dip.html|title= Strong French Manga Market Begins to Dip|author= Brigid Alverson|date= February 12, 2014|accessdate= December 14, 2014|work= publishersweekly.com}}</ref> surpassing [[Franco-Belgian comics]] for the first time.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bleedingcool.com/2014/01/french-comics-in-2013-its-not-all-asterix-but-quite-a-bit-is/|title= French Comics In 2013 – It’s Not All Asterix. But Quite A Bit Is.|author= Rich Johnston|date= January 1, 2014|accessdate= December 14, 2014|work= bleedingcool.com}}</ref>
====Manga made in France==== {{main|Manfra}} A surge in the growth of manga publishing circa 1996 coincided with the ''Club Dorothée'' show losing its audience – which eventually led to the show going off the air. Some early publishers like [[Glénat (publisher)|Glénat]], adapted manga using the Western reading direction and its induced work of mirroring each panel and graphical signs, and also using a quality paper standard to the Franco-Belgian comics, while others, like [[J'ai Lu]], were faithful to the original manga culture and not only kept the original, inverted, Japanese direction reading but also used a newspaper standard, cheap quality, paper just like in Japan. The Japanese manga was such an important cultural phenomenon that it quickly influenced French comics authors. A new "French manga" genre emerged, known as "La nouvelle manga" ("lit. the new manga") in reference to the French [[Nouvelle Vague]].
{{details|La nouvelle manga}} {{details|Franco-Belgian comics}}
===Spain===
Much like France, television had a large part in influencing the popularity of Japanese Manga, particularly with ''Dragon Ball'' and ''Saint Saiya'' showing up in the early nineties. Manga shook up the Spanish comics industry with new publishers taking in different directions with mostly publishing up manga instead of European comics.<ref name="google1">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.at/books?id=Z3zjBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT405&dq=manga+germany&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwif4fyUgbfYAhXDLcAKHXPiB28Q6AEINjAC#v=onepage&q=manga+germany&f=false|title=Manga: An Anthology of Global and Cultural Perspectives|first=Toni|last=Johnson-Woods|date=15 April 2010|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing USA|via=Google Books}}</ref>
===Italy===
Since late 1970s, Italy had many anime broadcast on private channels, taking a great popularity to japanese animation. Unfortunately, many of these were censored on some channels and for this reason some anime were not taken very seriously. Many Manga drawn by Italian artists were also released, based on these censored versions. The publishing of Akira took an interest in older readers picking up other manga in the same vein. Italy had a high acceptance of comics with violence and nudity which contributed to this development. The very first un-flipped version of a manga was ''Dragon Ball'' released for the very first time in a tankōbon format.<ref name="google1"/>
===Germany=== Unlike its European neighbours, Germany never had a vibrant local comic production.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=ThfHNyM3f-4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Manga:+An+Anthology+of+Global+and+Cultural+Perspectives&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjy_Iffg5DZAhUMbawKHRl3Ce0Q6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=Manga%3A%20An%20Anthology%20of%20Global%20and%20Cultural%20Perspectives&f=false|title=Manga: An Anthology of Global and Cultural Perspectives|editor=Toni Johnson-Woods|isbn=0826429386|publisher=A&C Black|publication-date=2010}}</ref> A volume of ''[[Barefoot Gen]]'' was licensed in Germany in the 1980s, as was ''[[Japan Inc.]]'', published by small presses. ''[[Akira (manga)|Akira]]'''s first volume was not very popular. Paul Malone attributes the wider distribution of manga in the late 1990s to the fledgling commercial television stations showing dubbed [[anime]], which led to the popularity of manga. Malone also notes that the native German comics market collapsed at the end of the 1990s.<ref>{{Cite book|author=Malone, Paul M. |chapter=From [[Bravo (magazine)|Bravo]] to Animexx.de to Export | editor-last=Levi|editor-first=Antonia|editor2-last=McHarry|editor2-first=Mark| editor3-last=Pagliassotti|editor3-first=Dru |title=[[Boys' Love Manga: Essays on the Sexual Ambiguity and Cross-Cultural Fandom of the Genre]]| publisher=[[McFarland & Company]] |publication-date=2010|isbn=978-0-7864-4195-2|pages=23–24|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}</ref> Manga began outselling other comics in 2000.<ref name="intersections.anu.edu.au">{{cite web|url=http://intersections.anu.edu.au/issue20/malone.htm |title=Intersections: Home-grown Shōjo Manga and the Rise of Boys' Love among Germany's 'Forty-Niners' |publisher=Intersections.anu.edu.au |accessdate=2012-08-13}}</ref>
With a few other series like ''[[Appleseed (manga)|Appleseed]]'' in the following years, the "manga movement" picked up speed with the publication of ''[[Dragon Ball (franchise)|Dragon Ball]]'', an un-flipped German manga, in late 1996. In 2007, manga accounted for approximately 70–75% of all comics published in Germany.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/0,1518,525417,00.html |title=Europe's Manga Mania |author=Jennifer Fishbein |date=2007-12-27|accessdate= 2012-01-30|work=Spiegel Online International}}</ref>
===Portugal=== In [[Portugal]], manga has been published by Bertrand, Devir, Mangaline, Meribérica/Líber, [[Planeta DeAgostini]] and [[Texto Editora]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bedeteca.com/index.php?pageID=recortes&recortesID=2365|title= Presente e futuro da edição de manga em Portugal|author= Pedro Cleto|date= 3 January 2009|accessdate= 14 December 2014|work= bedeteca.com|language= Portuguese}}</ref> The first manga published in Portugal were ''[[Ranma ½]]'' and ''[[Spriggan (manga)|Spriggan]]'', both in 1995.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bedeteca.com/index.php?pageID=recortes&recortesID=1555|title= Fenómeno Manga ameaça explosão |author= Pedro Cleto|date= 15 November 2004|accessdate= 14 December 2014|work= bedeteca.com|language= Portuguese}}</ref> There is a magazine of manga-inspired [[Portuguese comics]], ''Banzai''.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://p3.publico.pt/cultura/livros/1953/banzai-manga-com-prioridade|title= Banzai, manga com prioridade|author= Luís Octávio Costa|date= 13 January 2012|accessdate= 14 December 2014|work= [[Público (Portugal)|Público]]|language= Portuguese}}</ref>
===Russia=== Comics never gained high popularity in [[Russia]], only few [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]]'s titles being a moderate success.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mirf.ru/Articles/art1956.htm|script-title=ru:Врата Миров: Фантастические комиксы |last=Zlotnitsky|first=Dmitry |date = May 2007|work=№45|trans-title=Gate of the Worlds: Science fiction comics |publisher=[[Mir Fantastiki]] |language=Russian|accessdate=14 February 2010}}</ref> Russian readers traditionally considered them [[children's literature]], so the manga market developed late.<ref name="russia">"[http://www.echo.msk.ru/programs/razvorot/512241-echo/ Culture of manga and anime in Russia]" (in Russian). Interview with Satoshi Endo (May 5, 2008). ''[[Echo of Moscow]]''. Retrieved on 2008-11-26.</ref><ref name="rbk">{{cite web | url = http://www.rbcdaily.ru/2007/03/13/media/268001 |title = The adventures of manga in Russia: Kodansha International is looking for partners | publisher = [[RBK Daily]] |author1=Anastasia Vasilyeva |author2=Olga Goncharova | accessdate =2008-11-19| date =March 13, 2007|language=Russian}}</ref> A strong movement of anime fans helped to spread manga.<ref name="chedrik">{{cite web|url=http://chedrik.ru/up2/content/view/211/40/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110309092400/http://chedrik.ru/up2/content/view/211/40/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 9, 2011 |script-title=ru:Круглый стол для издателей и читателей. Тема круглого стола: "Судьба манги в России. Манга как часть визуальной культуры" |last=Olgerd |first=O. |author2=Kunin A. |date=May 8, 2010 |publisher=Chedrik Chronicles |language=Russian |accessdate=10 June 2010 |trans-title=Round table for publishers and readers. The fate of the manga in Russia. Manga as part of visual culture. }}</ref> The [[general director]] of [[Egmont Publishing|Egmont Russia]] Lev Yelin commented that the most popular manga series in Japan are comics which "contain sex and violence", so they probably won't be published in Russia.<ref name="rbk"/> A representative of [[Sakura Press]] (the licensor and publisher of ''[[Ranma ½]]'', ''[[Gunslinger Girl]]'' and some other titles) noted that although this niche is promising, it's hard to advance on the market, because "in Russia comics are considered children's literature".<ref name="rbk"/> It is also impossible for publishers to predict the success or failure of any specific title.<ref name="chedrik"/> On the contrary, [[Rosmen]]'s general director Mikhail Markotkin said the whole popularity of comics doesn't matter, as only artistic talent and good story make a successful project, and only such manga "will work" on the market.<ref name="chedrik"/>
The first officially licensed and published manga series in Russia was ''Ranma ½''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sakura-press.ru/about/|title=About Sakura Press|publisher=[[Sakura Press]] official website|language=Russian|accessdate=22 December 2009}}</ref> Sakura Press released the first volume in 2005.<ref name="chedrik"/> Since then several legal companies appeared, including [[Comics Factory]] and [[Comix-ART]]. Comix-ART, which is working in collaboration with [[Eksmo]], one of the largest publishing houses in Russia,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.rbcdaily.ru/2007/10/04/media/296566 | title =Eksmo Consolidates the Market| publisher = [[RBK Daily]] |author=Anastasia Vasilyeva| accessdate =2008-11-19| date =October 4, 2007|language=Russian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://rating.rbc.ru/article.shtml?2006/04/10/12577784 | title = Top 20 Russian Publishers | publisher = [[RBK Daily]] |accessdate =2008-11-19| date =April 10, 2006|language=Russian}}</ref> was the first company to publish [[Original English-language manga]] (usually called "manga" or just "comics"), such as ''[[Bizenghast]]'', ''Shutterbox'' and ''[[Van Von Hunter]]''.
===Poland=== Manga has been published in Poland since 90s when owner (Japanese person) of one of biggest publisher (J.P.F.) translated Dragon Ball into polish to practice with this language. Later he decided to publish his work. The publisher is known from series like DB, One Piece, Bleach and many others including Junjo Ito horrors or well known, old josei manga. Next to JPF we have publishers like Waneko or Studio JG known as 2 others top 3 biggest in Poland. Waneko is well known from publishing the biggest number of manga monthly and series like GTO, Kuroshitsuji, Pandora Hearts or Bakuman. They are also very known from publishing less popular series like Bokura no Kiseki. Studio JG makes a lot of controversy by making long breaks between manga volumes, many fans are very frustrated by their attitude. They are known from series like Toradora or Spice and Wolf. Behind that there are publishers like Yumegari (manhwa mainly although), Kotori (known from Sword Art Light Novel and many yaoi manga) or Dango which is the youngest from all polish publisher. Dango is very much appreciated by fans due to good quality of volumes and many extra free gadgets included. Yaoi manga are well selling in Poland. The other publisher which really deserve attention is Hanami. They are well known from more mature manga like Monster or Pluto.
==North America==
===United States=== The growth of manga translation and publishing in the United States has been a slow progression over several decades. The earliest manga-derived series to be released in the United States was a redrawn American adaptation of [[Osamu Tezuka]]'s ''[[Astro Boy]]'' published by [[Gold Key Comics]] starting in 1965.<ref>Schodt, Frederick, ''The Astro Boy Essays: Osamu Tezuka, Mighty Atom, and the Manga/Anime Revolution'' Pages 88, 89 & 91, Stone Bridge Press, 2007 {{ISBN|978-1-933330-54-9}}</ref>
In 1979, the Gold Key published the comic book [[Battle of the Planets (comics)|Battle of Planets]], based on a television series [[Battle of the Planets|of the same name]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Hofius, Jason |author2=George Khoury |title=G-Force Animated|publisher=[[TwoMorrows Publishing]], 2002|isbn=9781893905184}}</ref> Marvel published a series based [[Shogun Warriors (toys)|Shogun Warriors]], bringing characters of the [[mecha anime and manga]] series: [[Brave Raideen]], [[Chodenji Robo Combattler V]] and [[Wakusei Robo Danguard Ace]].<ref>{{cite journal|last= Smith|first= Andy|title= ''Shogun Warriors'' The Sky-High Rise and Abrupt Fall of Three Giant Robots in Comics|journal= [[Back Issue!]]|issue= 72|pages= 56–57|publisher= [[TwoMorrows Publishing]]|date= May 2014|quote= Even maintaining the same spelling of the robots' names between the toys and the comics didn't seem to be a top priority. Fans will find multiple versions of the word 'Combatra', sometimes as 'Combattra' and 'Raydeen', at times as 'Raideen', adorning the boxes of some of the figures.}}</ref>
The first manga to be published in the US with its original artwork intact was Nakazawa's major work ''[[Barefoot Gen]]'' published in 1979 – brought over by [[Frederik Schodt]] and Jared Cook with funds raised from their Project Gen charity,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Clements|first1=Jonathan|title=Schoolgirl Milky Crisis|date=2008|publisher=Titan Books|isbn=9781848560833|page=28|edition=First}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Schott|first1=Frederick|title=Biography|url=http://www.jai2.com/Mybiblio.htm|website=JAI2|accessdate=14 June 2015}}</ref> In December 1982 the [[San Francisco]]-based publisher Educomics released a colorized and translated version of [[Keiji Nakazawa]]'s ''I Saw It''. Four translated volumes of it were also published in the early 1980s by New Society Publishers.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090604111623/http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA6287306.html|archivedate=June 4, 2009|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA6287306.html|title=Manga and the Atomic Bomb: Barefoot Gen Returns|author=Kai-Ming Cha|publisher=www.publishersweekly.com|date=November 29, 2005|accessdate=November 10, 2015}}</ref> Short works by several ''[[Garo (magazine)|Garo]]''-affiliated artists including [[Yoshiharu Tsuge]] and [[Terry Yumura]] appeared in May 1985 in ''[[RAW (magazine)|RAW]]'''s no. 7 "Tokyo Raw" special.
In 1987, [[Viz Comics]], an American subsidiary of the Japanese publishers [[Shogakukan]] and [[Shueisha]], began publishing translations of three manga series – ''[[Area 88]]'', ''[[Mai the Psychic Girl]]'', and ''[[The Legend of Kamui]]'' – in the U.S. in association with the American publisher [[Eclipse Comics]]. Viz went on to bring English translations of popular series such as ''Ranma ½'' and ''[[Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (manga)|Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind]]'' in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Some other American publishers released notable translations of Japanese comics in this period, such as [[First Comics]]' serialization of ''[[Lone Wolf and Cub]]'' which started in May 1987. However, the first manga to make a strong impression on American audiences was [[Katsuhiro Otomo]]'s ''[[Akira (manga)|Akira]]'', which was brought to the United States in colorized form in 1988 by [[Epic Comics]], a division of [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]].<ref name="akira-2019">{{cite web | last = akira2019.com| year = 2005| url = http://www.akira2019.com/akira-marvel-epic-comics.htm| archive-url = https://archive.is/20131021194051/http://www.akira2019.com/akira-marvel-epic-comics.htm| dead-url = yes| archive-date = 21 October 2013| title = Marvel/Epic Comics: Akira Coloured Comic Book | publisher = akira2019.com| accessdate = 29 May 2007}} </ref><!--This dead link can not be retrieved/replaced on Wayback Internet Archive due to Robots.txt.-->
Throughout the 1990s, manga slowly gained popularity as Viz Media, [[Dark Horse Comics|Dark Horse]] and Mixx (now [[Tokyopop]]) released more titles for the US market. Both Mixx and Viz published manga anthologies: ''MixxZine'' (1997–1999) ran serialized manga such as ''[[Sailor Moon]]'', ''[[Magic Knight Rayearth]]'' and ''[[Ice Blade]]'', while Viz's ''[[Animerica Extra]]'' (1998–2004) featured series including ''[[Fushigi Yugi]]'', ''[[Banana Fish]]'' and ''[[Revolutionary Girl Utena|Utena: Revolutionary Girl]]''. In 2002 Viz began publishing a monthly American edition of the famous Japanese "phone book"-style manga anthology ''[[Weekly Shōnen Jump|Shōnen Jump]]'' featuring some of the most popular manga titles from Japan, including ''[[Dragon Ball Z#Manga|Dragon Ball Z]]'', ''[[Naruto]]'', ''[[Bleach (manga)|Bleach]]'' and [[One Piece]]. Its circulation far surpassed that of previous American manga anthologies, reaching 180,000 in 2005.<ref name="shonen-jump-circulation">{{cite web| last = Viz Media LLC | year = 2005| url = http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2005-12-06/viz-media-announces-anniversarry-edition-of-shonen-jump| title = Viz Media Announces Anniversarry {{sic|hide=y|reason=spelling error in source title}} Edition of Shonen Jump | publisher = Anime News Network| accessdate = 29 May 2007}}</ref> Also in 2005, Viz launched ''[[Shojo Beat]]'', a successful counterpart to ''Shonen Jump'' aimed at female readers.
In 2002, Tokyopop introduced its "100% Authentic Manga" line, which featured unflipped pages and were smaller in size than most other translated graphic novels. This allowed them be retailed at a price lower than that of comparable publications by Viz and others. The line was also made widely available in mainstream bookstores such as [[Borders Group|Borders]] and [[Barnes & Noble]], which greatly increased manga's visibility among the book-buying public.<ref name="tokyopop-authenticmanga">{{cite web| last = Tokyopop | year = 2002| url = http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2002-08-01/tokyopop-manga-sells-out| title = Tokyopop manga Sells Out | publisher = Anime News Network| accessdate = 29 May 2007}}</ref> After Tokyopop's success, most of the other manga companies switched to the smaller unflipped format and offered their titles at similar prices.
A large number of small companies in the United States publish manga. Several large publishers have also released, or expressed interest in releasing manga. [[Del Rey Manga|Del Rey]] translated and published several Japanese series including ''[[xxxHolic]]'', ''[[Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle]]'' and, ''[[Negima!: Magister Negi Magi]]'', while [[Harlequin Enterprises|Harlequin]] has brought its Ginger Blossom line of manga, originally released only in Japan, to the United States as well.
==Africa== ===Algeria=== {{main|DZ-manga}}
==Oceania== In Australia and New Zealand, many popular Japanese- and Chinese-language manga and [[anime]] are distributed by [[Madman Entertainment]].
==South America==
===Brazil=== Before the 1990s some trial marketing of manga took place in Brazil, including ''[[Lone Wolf and Cub]]'', the first one published in the country in 1988,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mundoestranho.abril.com.br/materia/quando-surgiram-os-primeiros-mangas-e-animes|title=Quando surgiram os primeiros mangás e animês?|trans-title=When arose the first manga and anime?|author=Goto, Marcel|publisher=Mundo Estranho|language=Portuguese}}</ref> ''[[Mai, the Psychic Girl]]'', ''[[Akira (manga)|Akira]]'', ''[[Cobra (manga)|Cobra]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.universohq.com/quadrinhos/2005/review_cobra.cfm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051018124002/http://www.universohq.com/quadrinhos/2005/review_cobra.cfm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2005-10-18 |title=Cobra |author=Naranjo, Marcelo |publisher=Universo HQ |language=Portuguese }}</ref> ''[[Crying Freeman]]'', and ''[[The Legend of Kamui]]''. The Brazilian ''shōnen'' market started in the mid-1990s with ''[[Ranma ½]]'' published by Animangá, although the publication did not prove successful (due to the fact that it was released in the American format and contained only two chapters per issue, roughly equivalent to one fourth of a ''tankohon'').<ref name="hq">{{cite web|url=http://www.universohq.com/quadrinhos/2010/Animanga.cfm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100905031439/http://www.universohq.com/quadrinhos/2010/Animanga.cfm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 5, 2010 |title=Relembrando a aventura de Ranma ½ pela Animangá |trans-title=Remembering the adventure of Ranma ½ by Animangá |date=August 31, 2010 |author=Domingues, Guilherme K. |publisher=Universo HQ |language=Portuguese }}</ref> It was followed by ''[[Pokémon: The Electric Tale of Pikachu]]'', released by Conrad in 1999, during the ''[[Pokémon]]'' boom.
In 2000, Conrad published ''[[Saint Seiya]]'' and ''[[Dragon Ball]]'' (both titles already well known, since the equivalent anime had been highly successful in the 1990s).<ref name="hq"/> After the success of these titles, Conrad released not only trendy manga like ''[[One Piece]]'', [[Vagabond (manga)|''Vagabond'']], [[Neon Genesis Evangelion (manga)|''Neon Genesis Evangelion'']], and [[Slam Dunk (manga)|''Slam Dunk'']], but also classic manga like [[Osamu Tezuka]] titles (including [[Adolf (manga)|''Adolf'']] and [[Buddha (manga)|''Buddha'']]), [[Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (manga)|''Nausicaä'']], and less known titles like ''[[Bambi and Her Pink Gun]]'' and ''[[Sade (manga)|Sade]]''.
In 2003, the Japanese-Brazilian company Japan Brazil Communication (JBC) started publishing manga, releasing ''[[Rurouni Kenshin]]'', ''[[Magic Knight Rayearth]]'', ''[[Cardcaptor Sakura]]'' and ''[[Video Girl Ai]]''. In 2009, JBC published Clamp titles like ''[[X/1999]]'', ''[[Tsubasa Reservoir Chronicle]]'' and ''[[xxxHolic]]'', and popular titles like ''[[Inuyasha]]'', ''[[Negima!]]'', ''[[Fruits Basket]]'', ''[[Death Note]]'', ''[[Fullmetal Alchemist]]'', ''[[Yu-Gi-Oh!]]'', ''[[Shaman King]]'', ''[[Love Hina]]'' and ''[[Bakuman]]'', having also picked up the publishing rights for ''Ranma ½'' and ''Neon Genesis Evangelion'' in the same year.
In 2004, Panini started publishing manga, with the release of ''[[Peach Girl]]'' and ''[[Eden: It's an Endless World|Eden]]''. In 2012, Panini published the most popular manga in Brazil: ''[[Naruto]]'' and [[Bleach (manga)|''Bleach'']], as well as titles like ''[[Black Lagoon]]'', ''[[Highschool of the Dead]]'', ''[[Full Metal Panic!]]'' and ''[[Welcome to the N.H.K.]]''. Panini has also, in 2012, acquired the publishing rights to ''One Piece'' in Brazil, continuing publication from where Conrad had stopped (Japanese volume 37) as well as reprinting earlier volumes in the original Japanese format.
Originally, Brazilian manga appeared with about half the size of a tankoubon (about 100 pages of stories and two to eight pages of extras), but almost all of the manga is released in the original format.
After years of negotiation, JBC finally released [[Sailor Moon]] in early 2014. The edition, regarded as the most important release ever done by the company, was reportedly praised by creator [[Naoko Takeuchi]] and [[Kodansha]] employees, thanks to its quality.
==Other distribution methods== Another popular form of manga distribution outside Japan involves Internet [[scanlation]]s (or ''scanslations''). Typically, a small group of people scan the original version of a series with no current license in the language which they wish to translate it to, translate it, and freely distribute it; usually through the use of [[IRC]] or [[BitTorrent (protocol)|BitTorrent]].
==Manga influences== {{Globalize|date=December 2010}} Manga has proved so popular that it has led to other companies such as [[Antarctic Press]], [[Oni Press]], [[Seven Seas Entertainment]] and Tokyopop, as well as long-established publishers like [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]] and [[Archie Comics]], to release their own manga-inspired works that apply the same artistic stylings and story pacing commonly seen in Japanese manga. One of the first of these such works came in 1985 when [[Ben Dunn]], founder of [[Antarctic Press]], released ''[[Mangazine]]'' and ''[[Ninja High School]]''.
While [[Antarctic Press]] actively refers to its works as "[[Manga-influenced comics|American Manga]]", it does not source all of these manga-inspired works from the United States. Many of the artists working on [[Seven Seas Entertainment]] series such as ''[[Last Hope (manga)]]'' and ''[[Amazing Agent Luna]]'' are [[Philippines|Filipino]] and TOKYOPOP has hired a variety of Korean and Japanese artists to work on titles such as ''[[Warcraft]]'' and ''[[Princess Ai]]''. Many of these works have been classified on the Internet with titles such as [[Manga-influenced comics|OEL Manga]], [[Manga-influenced comics|MIC]], and [[Manga-influenced comics|World Manga]], although none of these terms have actually been used by manga companies to describe these works on the books themselves.
In Brazil, the popularity of manga is marked also by the large number of Japanese and descendants in the country. In the 1960s, some of Japanese descent, such as Minami Keizi and Claudio Seto, started using graphic influences, narratives or manga themes in their work in EDREL publisher founded by Keizi.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070225223524/http://www.eca.usp.br/agaque/nucleousp/downloads/MinamiKeizi%20-%20Artigo%20INTERCOM%20%28por%20Elydio%20dos%20Santos%20Neto%29.pdf Minami Keizi, a Edrel e as HQs brasileiras: Memórias do desenhista, do roteirista e do editor] (in Portuguese). [[Escola de Comunicações e Artes da Universidade de São Paulo]].</ref>
In Germany, as manga began outselling domestic comics in 2000, German publishers began supporting German creators of manga-styled comics. Jürgen Seebeck's ''Bloody Circus'' was not popular amongst German manga readers due to its European style, and other early German manga artists were affected by cancellations. After this, German publishers began focussing on female creators, due to the popularity of shōjo manga, leading to what Paul Malone describes as a "home-grown shōjo boom", and "more female German comics artists in print than ever before". However, genuinely manga-influenced stylistic conventions, such as sweatdrops, are employed to ensure "authenticity", original German works are flipped to read in a right-to-left style familiar to manga readers, author's afterwords and sidebars are common, and many German manga take place in Asia.<ref name="intersections.anu.edu.au"/>
The Arabic language manga "Canary 1001" is by a group calling themselves Amateam, whose director is Wahid Jodar, from the United Arab Emirates.<ref name = "ama">{{cite web|author=Jul 17, 2010, 6:15:10 AM by ~AMATEAM |url=http://amateam.deviantart.com/ |title=AMATEAM on deviantART |publisher=Amateam.deviantart.com |date=2010-07-17 |accessdate=2012-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deviantart.com/print/13298972/?itemtypeids= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306024804/http://www.deviantart.com/print/13298972/?itemtypeids= |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-03-06 |title=deviantART Shop Framed Wall Art Prints & Canvas | Manga & Anime | Digital Media | Rina by artist ~AMATEAM |publisher=Deviantart.com |date=2010-07-24 |accessdate=2012-08-13 }}</ref> Another Arab language manga is ''[[Gold Ring]]'', by Qais Sedeki, from 2009, also from the United Arab Emirates.<ref>Nitin Nair 2009 "Manga: Qais Sedeki's graphic obsession."http://gulfnews.com/arts-entertainment/books/manga-qais-sedeki-s-graphic-obsession-1.504820</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pageflip.ae/profile.html |title=Pageflip Publishing | Profile |publisher=Pageflip.ae |accessdate=2012-08-13}}</ref><ref name = "GR">{{cite web|url=http://www.goldring.ae |title=سوار الذهب |publisher=Goldring.ae |accessdate=2012-08-13}}</ref> Both groups of artists use the word "manga" for their work.<ref name = "ama"/><ref name = "GR"/>
In May 2010, [[Glenat (publisher)|Glenat]] Spain introduced their new line of works known as ''Linea Gaijin''<ref>[http://www.gaijin.es/ Linea Gaijin Glenat], {{es icon}}</ref> which showcases the works of several Spanish and Latin American comic book artists. This is an effort on the part of Glenat to bring fresh new content and breed a new generation of manga-inspired artists that grew up reading manga. The line began with titles such as ''Bakemono'', ''Dos Espadas'', and ''Lettera'' that were shown on the ''[[Salón del Manga de Barcelona]]''<ref>[http://www.edicionesglenat.es/noticia.aspx?pId=771 Linea Gaijin released], {{es icon}}</ref> in October 2010, but it would later introduce other works as well.
Many Western [[webcomics]] are influenced to varying degrees by manga. Some, like [[Megatokyo]], follow traditional manga artwork and plotlines closely. Others, like [[Sinfest]] or [[Girly]], incorporate Western techniques and do not follow traditional Japanese manga story elements.

{{Use American English|date=September 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = My Little Pony: Equestria Girls – Rainbow Rocks | image = Rainbow Rocks Poster 2.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Jayson Thiessen]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Devon Cody * Sarah Wall }} | writer = [[Meghan McCarthy]] | based on = {{Plainlist| * {{based on|''[[My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic]]''|[[Lauren Faust]]}} }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Tara Strong]] * [[Ashleigh Ball]] * [[Andrea Libman]] * [[Tabitha St. Germain]] * [[Cathy Weseluck]] * [[Rebecca Shoichet]] * [[Kazumi Evans]] * [[Maryke Hendrikse]] * [[Diana Kaarina]] }} | music = William Anderson | editing = Rachel Kenzie | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[DHX Media]] * [[Hasbro Studios]] }} | distributor = [[Screenvision]] | released = {{Film date|2014|09|27}} | runtime = 71 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 71:00--><ref>{{cite web|title=''MY LITTLE PONY EQUESTRIA GIRLS: RAINBOW ROCKS'' (U)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/my-little-pony-equestria-girls-rainbow-rocks-2014|work=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=2014-09-27|accessdate=2015-10-07}}</ref> | country = {{Plainlist| * Canada * United States }} | language = English | gross = $347,511 {{Small|(Finland, Mexico, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, and Uruguay)}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?page=&country=UK&id=_fMYLITTLEPONYEQUE02|title=My Little Pony: Equestria Girls – Rainbow Rocks|work=boxofficemojo.com|accessdate=2015-07-17}}</ref> }} '''''My Little Pony: Equestria Girls – Rainbow Rocks''''' is a 2014 [[Canada|Canadian]]–[[United States|American]] [[Flash animation|Flash animated]] [[Fantasy film|fantasy]] [[musical film]] based on [[Hasbro]]'s [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls|Equestria Girls]] toy line and media franchise, which is a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] of the [[My Little Pony (2010 toyline)|2010 relaunch of My Little Pony]]. Written by [[Meghan McCarthy]] and directed by [[Jayson Thiessen]], the film was produced by [[DHX Media]]'s [[Studio B Productions|2D animation studio]] in [[Vancouver]], [[Canada]] for [[Hasbro Studios]] in the [[United States]], as a [[sequel]] to 2013's ''[[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls (film)|My Little Pony: Equestria Girls]]''. The film premiered in [[Limited release|select theaters]] across the United States and Canada on September 27, 2014, which was followed by broadcast on [[Discovery Family]], a [[joint venture]] between [[Discovery Communications]] and Hasbro, on October 17, 2014, and then a home media release on October 28, 2014.
Like the first film, ''Rainbow Rocks'' re-envisions the main characters of parent franchise, normally ponies, as teenage human characters in a [[high school]] setting. Set between the television series' [[My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic (season 4)|fourth]] and [[My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic (season 5)|fifth seasons]], the film's plot involves Twilight Sparkle returning to Canterlot High School to compete in a [[Battle of the Bands]] alongside the counterparts of her friends – including former school bully/former student of Princess Celestia Sunset Shimmer – to save the school from a trio of [[Siren (mythology)|sirens]] from Equestria.
The film was well received by critics, who described it as "far superior" to the first installment.<ref name = "VVreview">{{Cite web | url = http://www.villagevoice.com/2014-09-24/film/my-little-pony-equestria-girls-rainbow-rocks/ | title = For the Faithful, My Little Pony: Equestria Girls -- Rainbow Rocks Really Does Rock | first = Sherilyn | last = Connelly | date = 2014-09-24 | accessdate = 2014-09-25 | work = [[The Village Voice]] }}</ref><ref name = "HRreview">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/my-little-pony-equestria-girls-736163|title='My Little Pony: Equestria Girls – Rainbow Rocks': Film Review|first=Sheri|last=Linden|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=2014-09-27|accessdate=2014-09-27}}</ref> It was followed by two sequels, ''[[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls – Friendship Games|Friendship Games]]'' and ''[[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls – Legend of Everfree|Legend of Everfree]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/my-little-pony-equestria-girls-736163|title='My Little Pony: Equestria Girls – Legends of Everfree': Trailer|first=Breanne|last=Heldman|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=2014-07-22|accessdate=2016-07-22}}</ref>
==Plot== Former Canterlot High School bully & student of [[List of My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic characters#Princess Celestia|Princess Celestia]], [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Sunset Shimmer|Sunset Shimmer]], who has reformed after being defeated by the magic of [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Twilight Sparkle|Princess Twilight Sparkle]]'s crown, is ostracized by most of the school despite her efforts to atone for her actions. Her only friends are the counterparts of [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Rainbow Dash|Rainbow Dash]], [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Applejack|Applejack]], [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Pinkie Pie|Pinkie Pie]], [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Fluttershy|Fluttershy]] and [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Rarity|Rarity]], who have formed a rock band called "the Rainbooms" to participate in the school's upcoming musical showcase. The five girls discover that the magic left over from Twilight's crown has given them the ability to grow pony-like ears, tails, and wings whenever they play their instruments.
Hoping to make a fresh impression, Sunset gives a school tour to three new students – [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Dazzlings|Adagio Dazzle, Sonata Dusk, and Aria Blaze]] – and informs them of the showcase, unaware that they possess magical singing voices. Calling themselves "the Dazzlings", the trio perform a song that turns the other students aggressive and competitive towards each other, convincing them to turn the friendly showcase into a [[Battle of the Bands]]. Sunset and her friends are protected from the song by their own magic, but fail to convince the bewitched [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Principal Celestia|Principal Celestia]] and [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Vice Principal Luna|Vice Principal Luna]] of the danger. Sunset remembers a book that magically copies whatever she writes in it to another kept by [[List of My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic characters#Princess Celestia|Princess Celestia]], her mentor from the parallel world of Equestria, which she uses to send a message requesting Twilight's help.
Princess Celestia's book is delivered to Twilight's castle in Ponyville. Receiving Sunset's message, Twilight deduces that the Dazzlings are banished [[Siren (mythology)|sirens]] from Equestria that feed on negative emotions to fuel their singing powers for their goal of world conquest. Twilight uses the book's magic to reactivate the portal between worlds, allowing her and [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Spike|Spike]] to return to the parallel world. Twilight and the girls attempt to use the magic of their friendship to lift the Dazzlings' spell, but it takes no effect. Concluding that they must perform a musical counter-spell, the girls enter the Battle of the Bands to give Twilight time to complete the spell. The Rainbooms face hostility and sabotage from the bewitched bands throughout the competition, which raises existing tensions among Twilight's friends over conflicting aspects of their band.
Desperate for time in the semifinal round against [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Trixie|Trixie]]'s band, Rainbow Dash performs an egotistical song to substitute the counter-spell and nearly transforms, which forces Sunset to ruin her performance to keep her from exposing their plan to the Dazzlings. Despite this, the Dazzlings intervene to allow the Rainbooms' advancement to the final round, goading a jealous Trixie into trapping the Rainbooms beneath the stage to take their place. Isolated for hours, Twilight's friends enter a heated argument that allows the Dazzlings to absorb their magic. Realizing that their constant infighting is interfering with Twilight's spell, Sunset convinces the girls to resolve their differences, while Twilight reasons that simply playing together as friends will make the counter-spell work.
Spike rescues the girls with assistance from [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#DJ Pon-3|DJ Pon-3]], a student whose headphone music protects her from the Dazzlings' spell. DJ Pon-3 provides a sound system that the Rainbooms use to engage the Dazzlings in a musical battle. Overwhelmed by the Dazzlings' projected siren forms, the Rainbooms are joined by Sunset, who assumes her own pony-like form; with her help, the Rainbooms are able to destroy the pendants that provide the Dazzlings with their singing abilities, rendering the trio [[Tone deafness|tone-deaf]]. Returning to its harmonious state, the school drives the Dazzlings away and praises the Rainbooms. Twilight and Spike return to Equestria, while Sunset uses Princess Celestia's book to remain in contact with Twilight.
During the closing credits, a [[Montage (filmmaking)|montage]] plays showing Sunset being accepted by the student body and performing as the Rainbooms' new lead singer and guitarist. In a [[post-credits scene]], the human world's version of Twilight Sparkle is shown investigating the strange activity around Canterlot High.
==Cast== {{see also|List of My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic characters|My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Characters}} *[[Tara Strong]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Twilight Sparkle|Twilight Sparkle]], a studious "alicorn" ([[winged unicorn]]) and one of the crowned princesses of Equestria. She serves as the temporary [[lead vocalist]] of the Rainbooms, a band formed by the counterparts of her pony friends. Strong also voices Twilight's counterpart in the alternate universe in a [[post-credits scene]]. *[[Ashleigh Ball]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Rainbow Dash|Rainbow Dash]], the lead [[guitar]]ist and founder of the Rainbooms; and [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Applejack|Applejack]], the Rainbooms' [[Bass guitar|bassist]]. Their counterparts in Equestria as depicted in ''Friendship Is Magic'' also appear in the film. *[[Andrea Libman]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Pinkie Pie|Pinkie Pie]], the Rainbooms' [[Drum kit|drummer]]; and [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Fluttershy|Fluttershy]], who plays the [[tambourine]] on the Rainbooms. Their counterparts in Equestria also appear in the film. [[Shannon Chan-Kent]] performs Pinkie's singing voice. *[[Tabitha St. Germain]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Rarity|Rarity]], the Rainbooms' [[keytar]]ist; and [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Vice Principal Luna|Vice Principal Luna]], the [[vice-principal]] of Canterlot High and Celestia's younger sister. Rarity's counterpart in Equestria also appears in the film. *[[Cathy Weseluck]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Spike|Spike]], Twilight's young dragon assistant who assumes the form of a dog in the parallel world. His ordinary dog counterpart appears in a [[post-credits scene]]. *[[Rebecca Shoichet]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Sunset Shimmer|Sunset Shimmer]], a unicorn from Equestria and reformed school bully at Canterlot High who befriends the Rainbooms. Shoichet also performs Twilight Sparkle's singing voice. *[[Kazumi Evans]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Adagio Dazzle|Adagio Dazzle]], the leader of the power-hungry [[Siren (mythology)|sirens]] from Equestria and lead vocalist of the Dazzlings. Evans also performs Rarity's singing voice. *[[Maryke Hendrikse]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Sonata Dusk|Sonata Dusk]], an airheaded siren and [[backing vocalist]] of the Dazzlings. [[Madeline Merlo]] performs Sonata's singing voice. *[[Diana Kaarina]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Aria Blaze|Aria Blaze]], a temperamental siren and backing vocalist the Dazzlings. Shylo Sharity performs Aria's singing voice. *[[Vincent Tong]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Flash Sentry|Flash Sentry]], a student infatuated with Twilight who plays against her as guitarist of the Flash Drives,<ref>{{cite web|title=Flash Sentry character profile|url=http://equestriagirls.hasbro.com/en-us/girls/eg/flashsentry|publisher=Hasbro.com|accessdate=2016-08-19|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161010205140/http://equestriagirls.hasbro.com/en-us/girls/eg/flashsentry|archivedate=2016-10-10}}</ref> one of the rival bands. *[[Kathleen Barr]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Trixie|Trixie]]<!-- So far, the "Lulamoon" part of her name only appeared in toys. -->, a [[Magic (illusion)|magician]] and guitarist of another rival band, Trixie and the Illusions. *[[Nicole Oliver]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Principal Celestia|Principal Celestia]], the [[Head teacher|principal]] of Canterlot High. Her pony counterpart, Princess Celestia, is the ruler of Equestria and Sunset Shimmer's former mentor.
The [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#DJ Pon-3|counterpart of DJ Pon-3]] appears prominently in the film in a non-speaking role. The film features minor appearances from [[Michelle Creber]] as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Apple Bloom|Apple Bloom]]; Ingrid Nilson as a counterpart of [[List of My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic characters#Pie family|Maud Pie]], Pinkie Pie's sister; [[Peter New]] as a counterpart of [[List of My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic characters#Big McIntosh|Big McIntosh]]; [[Lee Tockar]] and [[Richard Ian Cox]] as the counterparts of [[List of My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic characters#Snips and Snails|Snips and Snails]]; Tabitha St. Germain as a counterpart of [[List of My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic characters#Photo Finish|Photo Finish]]; and [[Brian Drummond]] as a delivery pony in Equestria. Kazumi Evans also provides an uncredited line of dialogue as [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls#Octavia Melody|Octavia Melody]].<ref>{{citation|url=https://twitter.com/StTabitha/status/516395230203883520|title=[Octavia Melody's Official VA Confirmation]|last=St. Germain|first=Tabitha|publisher=Twitter|work=(Self-published)|date=2014-09-28|accessdate=2014-09-29}}{{dead link|date=October 2014}}</ref>
==Production== On February 13, 2014, Meghan McCarthy wrote on [[Twitter]] that she had worked on the film during the summer of 2013.<ref>{{citation|url=https://twitter.com/MMeghanMcCarthy/status/434026737148497920|title=["Rainbow Rocks" Production Work Confirmation]|publisher=[[Twitter]]|work=(Self-published)|date=2014-02-13|accessdate=2014-02-13|last=McCarthy|first=Meghan|postscript=.}}</ref> The film's opening credits were storyboarded by Tony Cliff.<ref>{{citation|url=https://twitter.com/ishiH3Art/status/515976023939104769|title=["Rainbow Rocks" Opening Credits Storyboard Artist Confirmation]|publisher=[[Twitter]]|work=(Self-published)|date=2014-09-27|accessdate=2014-09-27|last=Rudell|first=Ishi|postscript=.}}</ref> The storybook illustration depictions of the sirens in Equestria were done by Rebecca Dart.<ref name="commentary">{{cite web|url=http://www.toplessrobot.com/2014/10/the_15_coolest_things_from_the_my_little_pony_eque.php|title=The 14 Coolest Things from the My Little Pony: Equestria Girls – Rainbow Rocks DVD Commentary|last=Connelly|first=Sherrily|work=Topless Robot|date=2014-10-22|accessdate=2014-10-22}}</ref> The illustrations shown during the ending credits were drawn by Katrina Hadley.<ref>{{citation|url=https://twitter.com/ishiH3Art/status/515925459159109632|title=["Rainbow Rocks" Ending Credits Illustrations Artist Confirmation]|publisher=[[Twitter]]|work=(Self-published)|date=2014-09-27|accessdate=2014-09-27|last=Rudell|first=Ishi|postscript=.}}</ref>
In the audio commentary included in home media releases, Meghan McCarthy commented that ''Equestria Girls'' was initially not intended to become an ongoing franchise, and the thought of a sequel did not cross her mind. Additionally, Sunset did not become a main character until the second draft of the script.<ref name="commentary" /> The DVD commentary also points out that the midnight snack scene between Twilight and Sunset was actually added late into the film's production, Rarity's line "past...ahem...booboos" was [[Ad libitum|ad-lib]]bed by Germain, and the [[freestyle rap]] by Snips and Snails' counterparts was genuine freestyling by Lee Tockar and Richard Cox.<ref name="commentary" />
===Music=== {{main article|List of songs in My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic#Rainbow Rocks}} On February 13, 2014, songwriter [[Daniel Ingram (composer)|Daniel Ingram]] wrote on Twitter that there will be a total of 12 songs in the film, the greatest number of songs featured in a ''Friendship Is Magic'' episode or ''Equestria Girls'' film thus far;<ref>{{citation|url=https://twitter.com/dannyimusic/status/434123150721179648|title=[Number of Songs in "Rainbow Rocks" Confirmation]|publisher=[[Twitter]]|work=(Self-published)|date=2014-02-13|accessdate=2014-02-13|last=Ingram|first=Daniel|postscript=.}}</ref> however, only 11 songs made it in the film.
Like in ''Equestria Girls'', the songs were composed by Ingram with lyric writing shared between Ingram and screenwriter Meghan McCarthy; with the exception of "Rainbow Rocks" and "Shine Like Rainbows" which had lyrics by Ingram; "Bad Counter Spell" and "Under Our Spell" by McCarthy; and "Shake Your Tail" having a first draft by writer [[Amy Keating Rogers]], in which Ingram later revised.<ref>{{citation|url=https://twitter.com/KeatingRogers/status/521355672579870721|title=["Shake Your Tail" Credit Confirmation]|last=Rogers|first=Amy|publisher=Twitter|work=(Self-published)|date=2014-10-12|accessdate=2014-10-12}}</ref> Trevor Hoffman provided the arrangements for the songs, and musician Caleb Chan produced the songs as well as played guitar and bass.<ref name="ingramfacebook">{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/dannyimusic/posts/749566961757545|title=["Rainbow Rocks" soundtrack post]|first=Daniel|last=Ingram|publisher=Facebook|work=(Self-published)|date=2014-09-13|accessdate=2014-09-13}}</ref> *"Rainbow Rocks" – The Rainbooms (voiceover) *"Better Than Ever" – The Rainbooms sans Twilight Sparkle *"Battle"<!--do not add 'of the Bands'; the film's end credits has this song labeled as "Battle"--> – The Dazzlings and students *"Bad Counter Spell" – The Rainbooms *"Shake Your Tail" – The Rainbooms *"Under Our Spell" – The Dazzlings *"Tricks Up My Sleeve" – Trixie and the Illusions *"Awesome as I Wanna Be" – Rainbow Dash and the Rainbooms *"Welcome to the Show" – The Rainbooms, Sunset Shimmer, The Dazzlings, and students *"Rainbooms Battle" – Instrumental *"End Credits Song: Shine Like Rainbows" – The Rainbooms
==Release==
===Marketing=== On July 24, 2014, a movie clip and a teaser trailer were released on [[Yahoo!|Yahoo! TV]].<ref>{{cite web | url = https://tv.yahoo.com/blogs/tv-news/first-look---my-little-pony--posse-goes-up-against-a--mean--girl-group-in--equestria-girls-%E2%80%94-rainbow-rocks--003226065.html | title = First Look: 'My Little Pony' Posse Goes Up Against a (Mean) Girl Group In 'Equestria Girls – Rainbow Rocks' | publisher = [[Yahoo!|Yahoo! TV]] | date = 2014-07-24 | accessdate = 2014-07-24 }}</ref> On September 10, 2014, through the Equestria Daily fan news blog, [[Shout! Factory]] revealed a 30-second trailer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E5r0qa4aOBU|title=EQD Exclusive: Equestria Girls Rainbow Rocks 30 Second Shout Factory Promo|publisher=YouTube|date=2014-09-10|accessdate=2014-09-10}}</ref> Two days later on September 12, a 50-second trailer was released on [[YouTube]].<ref>{{cite video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gjJ4gLcdnIM|title=Equestria Girls Trailer Highlights More Characters!|publisher=YouTube|date=2014-09-12|accessdate=2014-09-12}}</ref> Six days later on September 18, a full theatrical trailer was released also via Yahoo! TV;<ref>{{cite web | url = https://tv.yahoo.com/video/little-pony-trailer-193654227.html | title = 'My Little Pony: Equestria Girls – Rainbow Rocks' Trailer | publisher = [[Yahoo!|Yahoo! TV]] | date = 2014-09-18 | accessdate = 2014-09-18 }}</ref> the trailer was then uploaded to Hasbro's YouTube channel four days later on September 22.<ref>{{cite video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M-N2Fn1tP3Q|title=MLP: Equestria Girls Rainbow Rocks – Official Movie Trailer #1|publisher=YouTube|date=2014-09-22|accessdate=2014-09-22}}</ref><!-- These trailers had no [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system#Advertising materials|classification card]] from the MPAA, even for the United States screenings. -->
===Theatrical=== The film received a [[Limited release|limited theatrical release]] on September 27, 2014, in the United States through [[Screenvision]] theaters and in Canada through [[Cineplex Entertainment|Cineplex]] theaters.<ref name="Screenvision">{{cite web | url = http://www.screenvision.com/cinema-events/my-little-pony-equestria-girls-rainbow-rocks/ | title = My Little Pony: Equestria Girls: Rainbow Rocks | publisher = [[Screenvision]] | date = 2014-07-18 | accessdate = 2014-07-19 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140722070931/http://www.screenvision.com/cinema-events/my-little-pony-equestria-girls-rainbow-rocks/ | archivedate = July 22, 2014 | df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cineplex.com/Movie/my-little-pony-equestria-girls-rainbow-rocks|title=Cineplex.Com – My Little Pony: Equestria Girls: Rainbow Rocks|publisher=Cineplex Entertainment, LLC|date=2014-08-06|accessdate=2014-08-06}}</ref> It also received a "Purple Carpet" premiere at the [[Grauman's Chinese Theatre|TCL Chinese Theatre]] in [[Hollywood]], which was attended by the cast and crew as well as some celebrities such as [[Jamie Foxx]], ''[[Modern Family]]'' actress [[Ariel Winter]], and [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nominee [[Quvenzhané Wallis]].<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.shoutfactory.com/editorials/rainbow-rocks-premiere | title = Rainbow Rocks Premiere | publisher = [[Shout! Factory]] | date = 2014-10-06 | accessdate = 2014-10-06 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150117181449/https://www.shoutfactory.com/editorials/rainbow-rocks-premiere# | archive-date = January 17, 2015 | dead-url = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Like the first film, the screenings of ''Rainbow Rocks'' in the United States [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system#Other labels|bore no classification]] from the [[MPAA]] (which is not a mandatory, although many theaters carried a G-rating), while the Canadian screenings had classifications from provincial film boards (usually G).
In the [[United Kingdom]], the film was theatrically released on October 25 and 26, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.myvue.com/latest-movies/info/film/my-little-pony-equestria-girls-rainbow-rocks|title=My Little Pony: Equestria Girls Rainbow Rocks|publisher=Myvue|date=2014-10-10|accessdate=2014-10-10}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The film was theatrically released on November 15, 2014, in [[Australia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eventcinemas.com.au/movie/My-Little-Pony-Equestria-Girls-2|title=My Little Pony Equestria Girls 2|publisher=Event Cinemas|date=2014-11-10|accessdate=2014-11-10}}</ref>
===Home media=== The film was released on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] by Shout! Factory on October 28, 2014, in [[DVD region code#1|Region 1]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Little-Equestria-Girls-Rainbow-Rocks/dp/B00LOCLDFE/ref=tmm_dvd_title_0|title=My Little Pony Equestria Girls Rainbow Rocks|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|date=2014-07-13|accessdate=2014-07-13}}</ref> Special features include a new featurette, the eight prelude animated shorts, a sing-along song, and an [[audio commentary]] on the film by writer Meghan McCarthy, director Jayson Thiessen, co-director Ishi Rudell, vice president of development at Hasbro Studios Michael Vogel, and Hasbro's executive director Brian Lenard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phase4films.com/Details.aspx?projectId=ca48cd13-b0cc-e311-a08d-d4ae527c3b65|title=My Little Pony Equestria Girls: Rainbow Rocks DVD Factsheet|work=Phase 4 Films|date=2014-07-01|accessdate=2014-08-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140822115519/http://www.phase4films.com/Details.aspx?projectId=ca48cd13-b0cc-e311-a08d-d4ae527c3b65|archivedate=August 22, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> There were also three store exclusives for the United States release of the DVD: The [[Target Corporation|Target]] edition included a bracelet, a [[United States dollar|USD]] $4 coupon for one My Little Pony toy, and the DVD of the first ''Equestria Girls'' film; The [[Walmart]] edition included a music CD, a digital copy of the film, and the same $4 coupon; The [[Kmart]] edition included a "backstage pass" and the coupon.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.therockfather.com/news-and-reviews/movie-and-tv/item/2900-my-little-pony-equestria-girls-rainbow-rocks-heads-home-on-blu-ray-and-dvd|title=My Little Pony Equestria Girls: Rainbow Rocks heads home on Blu-ray and DVD...|last=Zahn|first=James|work=The Rock Father|date=2014-10-13|accessdate=2014-10-13}}</ref> The initial production run of the DVD contained an error that caused chapters 5 and 6 to play in reverse order when the film was viewed using the "Play" option on the main menu.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://shoutfactory.com/film/film-animation/my-little-pony-equestria-girls-rainbow-rocks|title=My Little Pony: Equestria Girls – Rainbow Rocks|publisher=Shout! Factory|date=2014-10-28|accessdate=2014-10-28}}</ref>
A Region 2 ''Rainbow Rocks'' DVD from distributor Primal Screen Entertainment was released on March 23, 2015, for various countries, including [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Italy]], the [[Middle East]] region, [[Netherlands]], and [[United Kingdom]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/My-Little-Pony-Equestria-Rainbow/dp/B00PDOAFQW|title=My Little Pony: Equestria Girls – Rainbow Rocks [DVD]|publisher=Amazon U.K.|date=2014-11-16|accessdate=2014-11-16}}</ref>
Alongside ''Equestria Girls'' and ''Friendship Games'', this film was released in a box set on October 13, 2015 in Region 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/My-Little-Pony-Equestria-Lenticular/dp/B0112HPRLG/|title=My Little Pony: Equestria Girls (Three Movie Gift Set)|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|date=2015-07-23|accessdate=2015-07-23}}</ref>
===Television=== ''Rainbow Rocks'' made its United States television premiere on [[Discovery Family]] (a joint venture between [[Discovery Communications]] and [[Hasbro]]) on October 17, 2014.<ref name=mcn-rainbowrocks>{{cite web|title=Discovery Family Channel Sets ‘My Little Pony’ Film|url=http://www.multichannel.com/news/content/discovery-family-channel-acquires-my-little-pony-film/384587|website=Multichannel News|accessdate=19 October 2014}}</ref> The film premiered on the [[Family Channel (Canadian TV network)|Family Channel]] in Canada on November 8, 2014. In the United Kingdom, it premiered on [[Pop (UK and Ireland)|Pop]] on December 24, 2014.
==Merchandise and other media== {{Main|My Little Pony: Equestria Girls}} The film is a part of music-themed Rainbow Rocks lineup, a second installment in the [[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls]] toy line and media franchise, which was first displayed at the 2014 [[American International Toy Fair]].<ref name="HasPRFeb14">{{Cite press release|title=Hasbro Unveils Its Portfolio of Entertainment Brands and Innovative Must-Have Play Experiences at the 2014 American International Toy Fair|url=http://newsroom.hasbro.com/mediakit/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=825997|location=[[New York City]]|publisher=[[Hasbro]]|agency=[[Business Wire]]|date=2014-02-15|access-date=2016-10-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://toybuzz.org/news/hasbro-reveals-little-pony-lineup-toy-fair-2014/|title=Hasbro Reveals My Little Pony Lineup At Toy Fair 2014|publisher=ToyBuzz.org|date=2014-02-18|accessdate=2014-02-18}}</ref> [[Little, Brown and Company|LB Kids]] published two [[novelization]]s of the film, all written by Perdita Finn. A Rainbow Rocks missile command-type mini-game was added to the ''Hasbro Arcade'' mobile app on April 8, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/my-little-pony-friendship/id533173905?mt=8|title=Hasbro Arcade|publisher=[[iTunes]]|date=2014-04-08|accessdate=2014-07-14}}</ref>{{Better source|date=September 2016}} An issue of [[IDW Publishing|IDW]]'s ''Fiendship Is Magic'' features the sirens.
===Animated shorts===

Thank you! --> On February 13, 2014, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' released the first trailer;<ref>{{cite web | url = http://family-room.ew.com/2014/02/13/my-little-pony-equestria-girls-rainbow-rocks/ | title = 'My Little Pony Equestria Girls': Yes, there will be a sequel. And we've got a clip! EXCLUSIVE | publisher = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | last = Busis | first = Hillary | date = 2013-02-13 | accessdate = 2014-02-13 }}</ref> about four months later however, McCarthy confirmed on her Twitter post that the clips from that trailer "are separate shorts and not scenes in the movie."<ref>{{citation|url=https://twitter.com/MMeghanMcCarthy/status/479740194854158336|last=McCarthy|first=Meghan|title=[Separate Shorts, Not "Rainbow Rocks" Movie Clips Confirmation]|date=2014-06-19|publisher=[[Twitter]]|work=(Self-published)|accessdate=2014-06-19}}</ref> A series of eight animated shorts was released on [[Hasbro|Hasbro Studio]]'s [[YouTube]] channel in 2014 from March 27 to June 19 to promote the film.<ref name="shorts">{{citation|url=https://twitter.com/TheBiggestJim/status/449340182093766656|last=Miller|first=Jim|title=[Eight animated shorts confirmation]|publisher=[[Twitter]]|work=(Self-published)|date=2014-03-27|accessdate=2014-05-05}}</ref> The shorts were created by the ''Friendship Is Magic'' crew to tie into the film, and are considered "prequels" to the film's events, detailing how each of them discovered that they could awaken Equestrian magic within them by playing their respective instruments.<ref>{{citation|url=https://twitter.com/mktoon/status/451537095299846144|last=Vogel|first=Mike|title=[Prequel to "Rainbow Rocks" and Story Expansion on the Eight "Rainbow Rocks" Shorts Confirmation]|publisher=[[Twitter]]|work=(Self-published)|date=2014-04-02|accessdate=2014-07-14}}</ref>
The first eight shorts made their television debut on Discovery Family on May 30, 2015.<ref>{{cite report|url=http://media.press.discovery.com.s3.amazonaws.com/ugc/highlights/Discovery_Family_Channel_Monthly_Highlights_-_May_2015_vFINAL.pdf|title=Discovery Family Channel May 2015 Programming Highlights|publisher=Discovery Family|last=Grant|first=Katie|date=2015-05-01|accessdate=2015-05-01}}</ref>
